importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the news article reporting on the Mariners' playoff progress, highlighting a pivotal moment in their postseason campaign.
The date when the Mariners defeated the Yankees in the 1995 ALDS, which many believe saved baseball in Seattle, providing historical context for the team's significance.
The date when Bret Boone hit a game-tying homer in Game 4 of the 2001 ALCS, a key moment in Mariners postseason history referenced as a comparison to Suárez's recent performance.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current postseason of 2025 represents a critical moment for the Mariners, as they are within one win of their first World Series appearance in over two decades.

keyTakeAways: Eugenio Suárez hit a grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning to give the Seattle Mariners a 6-2 lead over the Toronto Blue Jays in a crucial playoff game.
This grand slam is only the second in Mariners postseason history, making it a historic moment for the franchise.
The Mariners now lead the series 3-2 and are just one win away from their first World Series appearance, breaking a 24-year drought.
The game marked a dramatic turning point after the Blue Jays had tied the series with two wins in Seattle, showing resilience and momentum shifts.
Cal Raleigh hit a game-tying home run in the eighth inning, a rare feat in Mariners playoff history, and is now tied with Aaron Judge for most home runs in a single AL season.
Suárez’s performance was emotionally significant, with him addressing fans and family in a postgame press conference, emphasizing personal and cultural meaning.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a pivotal playoff matchup, Eugenio Suárez hit a grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning to give the Seattle Mariners a 6-2 lead over the Toronto Blue Jays, marking only the second grand slam in franchise postseason history. The Mariners now lead the series 3-2 and are just one win away from their first World Series appearance in over two decades. The game followed a series of dramatic moments, including a key double play by Cal Raleigh and a tie-breaking run in the fifth inning. Suárez’s performance, which occurred in front of his family and fans, is viewed as a historic emotional milestone, especially given the franchise's long history of near-misses. The game also marked a rare instance of a game-tying homer in the eighth inning of a playoff game, echoing a 2001 moment from Bret Boone. With the Mariners set to play Game 6 in Toronto, this victory brings them closer than ever to achieving a milestone they have waited 24 years to reach.
title: Eugenio Suárez grand slam powers Seattle Mariners to within one win of first World Series
